author: Alison Burdo
title: PPA files suit, seeks $300K in fines from UberX
text:
PPA files suit, seeks $300K in fines from UberX Aug 31, 2015, 8:47am EDT Industries & Tags Alison Burdo Digital Producer Philadelphia Business Journal Alison Burdo Digital Producer Philadelphia Business Journal Home of the Day Submitted Will services like Uber, UberX and Lyft finally be legal in Philadelphia? The Philadelphia Parking Authority is once again going after UberX, seeking nearly $300,000 in fines just as a Pennsylvania lawmaker has announced legislation that would make the rideshare company legal in Philadelphia and the rest of the Commonwealth. City Council rethinks Drexel University food truck bill after backlash The PPA's complaint seeks to bar UberX service from Philadelphia and fine its San Francisco-based parent company, Uber Technologies Inc., about $1,000 a day for the past 10 months of illegal operations in the city, according to The Inquirer . In the complaint, the PPA says Uber announced in April that it had provided one million UberX rides in Philadelphia. "UberX is continuing to operate illegally," [PPA's executive director Vince] Fenerty said Friday. "No one is regulating them." The PPA regulates taxi and limousine services in Philadelphia and has opposed UberX's continued operation, saying UberX cars are not inspected and drivers are not trained. In previous enforcement actions, PPA has impounded UberX cars, fined UberX drivers, and fined Uber itself for operating an illegal dispatch service in the city, Fenerty said. The bill would also implement a zero tolerance policy on drug and alcohol use for drivers and also prevents people convicted of various crimes, including burglary, robbery and sexual offenses, from offering the services. In Philadelphia, the city's parking authority regulates the taxi industry and the agency has made adjustments to its policies to allow UberBLACK, however other rideshare variations are still not permitted.
